items.text:
Electronically signed by Wasim Nasir, MD on 09-07-2025 at 12:42:15 PM EDT
Care Team:
Wasim Nasir, MD, primary provider
Veronica Ercolani, NP, provider
Sabrina Burnham, Medical Assistant, staff

The patient is 19-year-old female, last seen on Tuesday, August 05, 2025, who presents with the following complaint(s):

Acne vulgaris (Follow Up) (Chief Complaint): The complaint involves Face. 
No significant family history. No history of procedure.
items.note:
Patient returns to clinic for a follow up on:

CC#1 Atopic dermatitis on the chest, and upper extremities, prescribed tacrolimus, and triamcinolone. Patient states improvement no itching. Wondering when it will start to fade.  Patient denies refills.

CC#2 Acne vulgaris on the face discussed Tretinoin. Patient states having a few flares on the cheek and forehead but doing better.  Patient denies tretinoin at this time

CC#3 Postinflammatory skin pigmentation change on the face, neck and chest. Some improvement but very slowly.

CC#4 Keratosis pilaris on the upper arms, recommended urea or salicylic acid. Patient states improvement   She did not use the urea or salicylic acid she was using the Triamcinolone.

items.text:
ALLERGIES: no known allergies
MEDICATIONS: b12, daily multivitamin, vitamin d3
DERMATOLOGIC: acne
GENERAL: asthma, influenza vaccine, pneumococcal vaccine, sunscreen
SURGERIES: no history of procedure
SOCIAL HISTORY: exercises regularly, non - drinker, non-smoker, not sexually active, single, never married. Patient denies: misuses drugs
FAMILY HISTORY: no significant family history

The patient reports: itching
The patient denies: chill, fatigue, fever

Height: 62.3 in | Weight: 105 lbs
Body Mass Index: 19.0

clear skin with no inflammatory or noninflammatory acne lesions, involving Face

Pink erythematous scaly plaques, involving Left Infraclavicular Chest - Medial, Right Mammary Chest - Superior Lateral Quadrant, bilateral Upper Arms

brown evenly colored patch(es), involving Face, Neck, Chest

myriad of erythematous horny follicular plugs, involving bilateral Upper Arms

Neurologic: Alert and Oriented to Name, Place and Person
Psychiatric: Appropriate mood and affect.

1. Acne vulgaris
	•	Problem: Chronic - Stable
	•	Morphology: clear skin with no inflammatory or noninflammatory acne lesions (Face)
	•	Body Surface Area (BSA): 2.4 %
	•	Location: Face
	•	Plan:
		◦	Discussed tretinoin 0.025% - patient declines at this time and will let us know if she would like to treat acne in the future
		◦	Medications: tretinoin 0.025 % Cream Topical, 1.0 Application, QD, 30 Days, 20 Grams. 1(one) application(s) topical every day. Pea sized amount to entire face and follow with moisturizer every other night. 
		◦	Follow Up: Friday, November 07, 2025 at 04:15 PM

2. Atopic dermatitis
	•	Problem: Chronic - Stable
	•	Morphology: Pink erythematous scaly plaques (Left Infraclavicular Chest - Medial, Right Mammary Chest - Superior Lateral Quadrant, Right Upper Arm, Left Upper Arm)
	•	Body Surface Area (BSA): 5.8 %
	•	Locations: Left Infraclavicular Chest - Medial, Right Mammary Chest - Superior Lateral Quadrant, Right Upper Arm, Left Upper Arm
	•	Plan:
		◦	Counseling
		◦	Medications: tacrolimus 0.1 % ointment topical, 1.0 Application, BID, 30 Days, 30 Grams, 2 Refills. 1(one) application(s) topical 2(two) times a day as maintenance until clear 
 	 	triamcinolone acetonide 0.1 % cream Topical, 1.0 Application, BID, 30 Days, 454 Grams. 1(one) application(s) topical 2(two) times a day x 2 weeks then d.c until future flare 
		◦	Follow Up: Friday, November 07, 2025 at 04:15 PM (Atopic dermatitis follow up)

3. Postinflammatory skin pigmentation change
	•	Problem: Chronic - Stable
	•	Morphology: brown evenly colored patch(es) (Face, Neck, Chest)
	•	Body Surface Area (BSA): 12.6 %
	•	Locations: Face, Neck, Chest
	•	Plan:
		◦	Reassurance

4. Keratosis pilaris
	•	Problem: Chronic - Stable
	•	Morphology: myriad of erythematous horny follicular plugs (Right Upper Arm, Left Upper Arm)
	•	Body Surface Area (BSA): 5.3 %
	•	Locations: Right Upper Arm, Left Upper Arm
	•	Plan:
		◦	Urea or Salicylic acid based moisturizer daily (CeraVe or Cetaphil)

Acne vulgaris
    Plan:
        - tretinoin 0.025 % Cream Topical, 1 Application, QD, 30 Days, 20 Grams. 1(one) application(s) topical every day. Pea sized amount to entire face and follow with moisturizer every other night. .
    Patient education:
        - http://dermnetnz.org/acne/
        - Acne is a common chronic disorder affecting the hair follicle and sebaceous gland, in which there is expansion and blockage of the follicle and inflammation. There are several variants. Acne affects males and females of all races and ethnicities. It is prevalent in adolescents and young adults, with 85% of 16-18 year olds affected. However, it may sometimes occur in children and adults of all ages. Acne is due to a combination of factors, such as familial tendency and acne bacteria. Flares of acne can be provoked by several factors such as medications and diet. Treatment for acne depends on its severity and includes topical and oral medications, light therapy, and laser treatment. Acne tends to improve after the age of 25 years but may persist, especially in females.

Atopic dermatitis
    Plan:
        - tacrolimus 0.1 % ointment topical, 1 Application, BID, 30 Days, 30 Grams, 2 Refills. 1(one) application(s) topical 2(two) times a day as maintenance until clear .
        - triamcinolone acetonide 0.1 % cream Topical, 1 Application, BID, 30 Days, 454 Grams. 1(one) application(s) topical 2(two) times a day x 2 weeks then d.c until future flare .
    Patient education:
        - Atopic Dermatitis is a chronic condition that can be controlled by either topical medications or light therapy.  It is recommended to follow treatment as prescribed and if condition worsens or does not improve within 4-6 weeks, to schedule a follow up appointment for reevaluation.  It is important to make sure to also apply over the counter creams to keep skin hydrated.  

Postinflammatory skin pigmentation change
    Patient education:
        - https://www.dermnetnz.org/topics/postinflammatory-hyperpigmentation/
        - Patches developed after skin inflammation. Will improve over time if kept out of the sun and further inflammation is prevented. Apply sunscreen to exposed areas daily.

Keratosis pilaris
    Patient education:
        - http://www.dermnetnz.org/acne/keratosis-pilaris.html
        - KP is a condition that forms when the body produces too much of a protein called keratin.  When this occurs, it can block hair follicles and cause bumps to form over the arms, thighs, cheeks, and buttocks.  This benign condition may clear up on its own by following the self-care measures listed below:

-Use warm water and limit bath time. Hot water and long showers or baths remove oils from the skin. Limit bath or shower time to about 10 minutes or less. Use warm, not hot, water.

-Be gentle to the skin. Avoid harsh, drying soaps. Gently remove dead skin (exfoliate) with a washcloth or loofah. Vigorous scrubbing or removal of hair follicle plugs may irritate the skin and aggravate the condition. After washing or bathing, gently pat or blot the skin with a towel so that some moisture remains.

-Try medicated creams. Apply an over-the-counter cream that contains urea (Nutraplus, Eucerin), lactic acid (AmLactin, Lac-Hydrin), alpha hydroxy acid or salicylic acid. These creams help loosen and remove dead skin cells. They also moisturize and soften dry skin. Put on this product before moisturizer.

-Moisturize. While the skin is still moist from bathing, apply a moisturizer that contains lanolin (Lansinoh, Medela), petroleum jelly (Vaseline) or glycerin (Glysolid). These ingredients soothe dry skin and help trap moisture. Thicker moisturizers work best, such as Eucerin and Cetaphil. Reapply the product to the affected skin several times a day.

-Use a humidifier. Low humidity dries out the skin. A portable home humidifier or one attached to your furnace will add moisture to the air inside your home.

-Avoid friction from tight clothes. Protect affected skin from the friction caused by wearing tight clothes.
